@dsquareddigest @DAaronovitch I think regulation (i.e. for safety) might be v good thing, but basic point: if one consenting adult wants to
@dsquareddigest Sorry, am financial dimwit! Are you talking about bailiffs situation?
@sophiehannahCB1 @DAaronovitch same reason why you might if for "sex" you substituted "collateralised debt obligations"
@dsquareddigest Oh, right - okay. Yes, I totally agree. And yes, this might be true of a lot of sex work, but there are *also* people who
@dsquareddigest freely choose to do it, manage it in a self-employed/in-control way - and the law has to be based on principle, doesn't it?
@dsquareddigest Let's say I decide, tomorrow, to set up as an escort, and freely choose only clients I like/respect - how can the law...
@sophiehannahCB1 if nothing else, public health grounds. You couldn't set up as a tea shop without quite a lot of red tape.
@dsquareddigest justify trying to stop me? On what grounds?
@sophiehannahCB1  ie, because unchecked, individual transactions can grow up into social structures with undesirable properties
@dsquareddigest Yes, I suppose so - as it is in schools, universities, hospitals - almost everywhere! Not sure how to run system in idea way
@dsquareddigest Yes, quite. I could strike a deal tomorrow with a close friend of mine who wanted to be a gigolo - where's the harm? I can
@dsquareddigest totally understand those who say 'Regulate industry properly' but am baffled by full-on prohibitionist position.
@sophiehannahCB1 case that I think is really hard for prohibitionists is commercial transactions between people who already know each other
@dsquareddigest but I passionately believe that there is nothing wrong AT ALL with buying sex from a willing vendor, or with selling it as a
@dsquareddigest willing vendor. And am rather terrified that many seem to think there is! It's not like drugs, where the pro-criminalisation
@dsquareddigest lobby can say, 'But drugs are bad.' Sex is not innately bad, harmful, wrong or dodgy - quite the opposite! (Though it can be
@dsquareddigest done grimly, of course, and be part of dodgy stuff, but still...)
@sophiehannahCB1 not an argument for a total ban, but the level of necessary regulation might be really quite intrusive.
@dsquareddigest @DAaronovitch sell sex and another wants to buy it, how can anyone justify forbidding that?
@sophiehannahCB1 @DAaronovitch as a worker in another wholly underregulated profession, you'd be surprised how big the externalities can get
@DAaronovitch Totally agree. Can't see any ethical justification for illegality of sex work in cases where all are consenting adults.
